title: How to Make Apple Cider Doughnuts

steps.headline: Boil the apple cider.
steps.description: Allow the cider to reduce to quarter of a cup and allow it to cool.

steps.headline: Mix the wet ingredients together.
steps.description: In a large bowl, beat the sugar with the butter until smooth, add the eggs, buttermilk and reduced apple cider.

steps.headline: Mix the dry ingredients in a separate medium bowl.
steps.description: Combine the flour, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, salt and nutmeg together.

steps.headline: Incorporate the two bowls.
steps.description: Sift the dry ingredients into the wet ingredient bowl. Fold the dry ingredients in; don't over-beat the mixture. For the best results and easier stirring, sift a small amount at a time between stirring.

steps.headline: Lightly flour the counter-top.
steps.description: Add the dough onto the counter and knead slightly just to combine without overworking the dough.

steps.headline: Use a rolling pin to roll the dough to a ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thickness.
Make doughnut circles.
steps.description: You can either use two circular cookie cutters (one larger than the other) to create doughnut circles or roll into small balls for holes.

steps.headline: Fry the doughnuts.
steps.description: Add canola oil into a deep pan, dutch oven, or wok, so it measures at least three inches deep. Fry a few doughnuts at a time, turning once or twice until they are browned and fully cooked through.

steps.headline: Drain the oils.
steps.description: Transfer the doughnuts onto paper towels.

steps.headline: Cover the doughnuts in the cinnamon sugar mixture.
steps.description: Work fast while the doughnuts are still "damp" and hot for the coating to stick.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Accompany these doughnuts with a glass of hot apple cider, sprinkled with cinnamon.

text: Boil the apple cider. Allow the cider to reduce to quarter of a cup and allow it to cool. Mix the wet ingredients together. In a large bowl, beat the sugar with the butter until smooth, add the eggs, buttermilk and reduced apple cider. Mix the dry ingredients in a separate medium bowl. Combine the flour, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, salt and nutmeg together. Incorporate the two bowls. Sift the dry ingredients into the wet ingredient bowl. Fold the dry ingredients in; don't over-beat the mixture. For the best results and easier stirring, sift a small amount at a time between stirring. Lightly flour the counter-top. Add the dough onto the counter and knead slightly just to combine without overworking the dough. Use a rolling pin to roll the dough to a ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thickness.  Make doughnut circles. You can either use two circular cookie cutters (one larger than the other) to create doughnut circles or roll into small balls for holes. Fry the doughnuts. Add canola oil into a deep pan, dutch oven, or wok, so it measures at least three inches deep. Fry a few doughnuts at a time, turning once or twice until they are browned and fully cooked through. Drain the oils. Transfer the doughnuts onto paper towels. Cover the doughnuts in the cinnamon sugar mixture. Work fast while the doughnuts are still "damp" and hot for the coating to stick. Serve. Accompany these doughnuts with a glass of hot apple cider, sprinkled with cinnamon.
